reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s initial reassurance that a narrow target doesn’t imply near-zero flourishing because optimization can “hone in” (flight/selection analogy). That point is relevant but not fully load-bearing for the overall essay, which later argues at length that whether we reach mostly-great futures depends on ethical convergence, motivation, trade, threats, and blockers; so refuting the opening move weakens the framing more than it collapses the core conclusions (moderate centrality). The counter-model (hard optimization for stability/proxy objectives producing stable but low-flourishing outcomes) is a real objection to the analogy’s implied inference and would force the author to specify conditions linking optimization targets to flourishing, but much of this concern is already acknowledged in the essay’s later sections about misaligned motivations and “blockers,” reducing marginal refutational force (moderate strength). The critique is mostly correct in pointing out objective-misalignment risks, but likely overstates by calling the opening move “load-bearing,” since the essay doesn’t ultimately rest its optimism on generic optimization (good but not perfect correctness). It is clear, focused, and has little fluff.
title: Optimization may lock onto stability proxies rather than flourishing
